summary: This is a 1995 memorandum opinion and order from the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois regarding pretrial motions in limine in the case 'United States v. Messino', a drug distribution and money laundering conspiracy case involving eight defendants. The judge, James Alesia, rules on numerous evidentiary issues including taint from suppressed evidence, witness testimony, admissibility of evidence regarding weapons, taxes, cash dealings, and spousal privilege.

connections.description: Legally married since 1968. The court discusses the applicability of the adverse spousal testimony privilege and confidential marital communications privilege.
Granata was a participant in taped conversations with Clement Messino, transmitting on behalf of the government. The government sought to play these tapes without Granata testifying.
Mention of a debt owed by Gray Chrystall to Christopher Richard Messino, which the government argued was evidence of the conspiracy.
The government's case included evidence that Paul Messino traveled to Florida to pick up cocaine for Clement Messino or others.
The opinion references that some defendants may have had sexual relationships with the same female witnesses, which the government argued was relevant to their stories.

events.title: Taint Hearing
events.description: The court conducted a hearing to determine what evidence would be suppressed as derived from leads attributable to already suppressed evidence in the drug conspiracy case.

events.title: Pretrial Motions Ruling
events.description: Judge James Alesia issued a memorandum opinion and order ruling on numerous pretrial motions in limine filed by the government and eight defendants.

keyFacts: The court ruled that no further evidence would be suppressed due to 'tainted leads,' applying the independent source and inevitable discovery doctrines to evidence like leases, boat information, witness identities, and bank records.
Judge Alesia allowed the government to recall certain witnesses during its case-in-chief to present evidence in a 'chronological, coherent manner.'

The court addressed sensitive issues including the admissibility of evidence about defendants' use of prostitutes (generally excluded as irrelevant/prejudicial) and sexual relationships with witnesses (allowed if presented non-inflammatorily).

Significant rulings were made on spousal privilege, with the court reserving judgment on whether Pamela Messino could assert the adverse spousal testimony privilege against her husband, defendant Clement Messino.

The court denied a request for additional peremptory challenges for the eight defendants, instead allotting the standard 10 challenges to be shared, with each defendant having sole authority over one challenge.
